subject: Re: [junit] A test to verify that an event is generated
msgSnippet: Q: Is threading required to verify generating the event? Avoiding it would be better. My general strategy involves attaching a spy listener to the event
messageBody:
Q: Is threading required to verify generating the event? Avoiding it would be better.

My general strategy involves attaching a spy listener to the event source, invoking the method, then examining the spy listener. The spy listener would simply collect events in a list for comparison with an expected list. The alternatives include counting the number of actual events fired or asking whether the event source fired *at least* the expected event.

>So said Kris Henderson on 4/16/2003 --------------------
>I searched the archives but wasn't able to find what I was looking for.
>If this has already been discussed a pointer to the thread would be
>appreciated.
>
>I want to write a JUnit test to verify that an event is generated when I
>call a method. It seems to work but I have two questions. Does anyone
>see any problems that might arise in this test? Is there a better/more
>prefered way to do this?
>
>Here is the code/pseudocode of the test case I came up with:
>
>public void testEventGenerated()
>{
> MyClassThatFiresAnEvent myClass = new MyClassThatFiresAnEvent();
>
> final Thread currentThread = Thread.currentThread();
>
> myClass.addMyEventListener(new MyEventListener()
> {
> public void somethingHappened(MyEvent event)
> {
> currentThread.interrupt();
> }
> });
>
> Thread thread = new Thread()
> {
> public void run()
> {
> myClass.callMethodThatFiresTheEvent();
> }
> };
> thread.start();
>
> try
> {
> currentThread.sleep(5000);
> fail("Timed out waiting for the event.");
> }
> catch(InterruptedException ie)
> {
> System.out.println("Expect this exception");
> }
>}
>
